Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends

Incremental approach yielding to large scale reform – The prevailing wisdom: Healthcare system is broken – The new advocates for reform: Business, labor & some large insurers – MA breakthrough spurs state legislatures across the country. – 2008: The healthcare election? – Consumer-driven division / conservatives consider, liberals lament
Incremental approach yielding to large scale reform
– The prevailing wisdom: Healthcare system is broken
– The new advocates for reform: Business, labor & some large insurers
– MA breakthrough spurs state legislatures across the country.
– 2008: The healthcare election?
– Consumer-driven division / conservatives consider, liberals lament

• Cost Containment
• Cost Containment

– Few if any proposed solutions
– Few if any proposed solutions

Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends

Expansion of children’s health and dental programs – SCHIP bills pass in House and Senate
Expansion of children’s health and dental programs
– SCHIP bills pass in House and Senate

• House version contains guaranteed dental benefit
• House version contains guaranteed dental benefit

• Senate version does not, but contains $200 million for dental grants. Also provides for premium assistance to eligible kids who join parent’s plans through work, but excludes assistance for stand-alone dental.
• Senate version does not, but contains $200 million for dental
grants. Also provides for premium assistance to eligible kids
who join parent’s plans through work, but excludes w h o

• Need is for a “veto-proof” reconciliation, as President Bush opposes expansion on grounds that expanded kid care lays the foundation for socialized medicine.
• Need is for a “veto-proof” reconciliation, as President Bush
opposes expansion on grounds that expanded kid care lays
the foundation for socialized medicine.

• Other issues: Medicare Advantage funding; $35 or $50 billion appropriation; anti crowd-out provisions; size of tobacco tax increases, comparative research components…
• Other issues: Medicare Advantage funding; $35 or $50 billion

Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends

– Thwarts states from directing SCHIP funds to kids above
– Thwarts states from directing SCHIP funds to kids above

250 percent FPL (affecting 17 states including CA)
250 percent FPL (affecting 17 states including CA)

• Kids above 250% of FPL must show proof of no insurance
• Kids above 250% of FPL must show proof of no insurance

for 1 full year (CA requires just 3 months)
for 1 full year (CA requires just 3 months)

• States must demonstrate 95% enrollment of Medicaid and SCHIP eligible kids under 200% FPL before extending coverage higher
• States must demonstrate 95% enrollment of Medicaid and
SCHIP eligible kids under 200% FPL before extending
coverage higher

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

• Regulatory micromanagement on the rise
• Regulatory micromanagement on the rise

– Language assistance, provider sufficiency (timely access), rate regulation, any willing provider, assignment of benefits, prompt payment, independent review, retroactive termination, etc…
– Language assistance, provider sufficiency (timely access), rate
regulation, any willing provider, assignment of benefits, prompt
payment, independent review, retroactive termination, etc…

• All intended to protect consumers from bad players and practices
• All intended to protect consumers from bad players and practices

• All intended to address complaints about health plans, not dental
• All intended to address complaints about health plans, not dental

• For low margin benefit like dental, these add up to “death by a
• For low margin benefit like dental, these add up to “death by a

thousand pinpricks”
thousand pinpricks”

– Emergence of the “plan enforcement model”
– Emergence of the “plan enforcement model”

• By regulating “practice of dentistry” through dental plans, we risk defection of dentists from panels, which equals higher costs, higher premiums and less access. (example, timely access regs)
• By regulating “practice of dentistry” through dental plans, we risk
defection of dentists from panels, which equals higher costs,
higher premiums and less access. (example, timely access regs)

Current State Issues: MA kicks it all off
Current State Issues:
MA kicks it all off

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

• Governor Mit Romney signs universal coverage in 06
• Governor Mit Romney signs universal coverage in 06

– Employer and individual mandates; establishes large state agency “the connector” to coordinate private and tax-supported plans with hospitals, physician groups and insurers; establishes rules, builds marketplace where conforming products matched with purchasers.
– Employer and individual mandates; establishes large state agency
“the connector” to coordinate private and tax-supported plans with
hospitals, physician groups and insurers; establishes rules, builds
marketplace where conforming products matched with purchasers.

– Signaled that Democrats and Republicans can compromise on
– Signaled that Democrats and Republicans can compromise on

healthcare if they put their hearts and minds to it
healthcare if they put their hearts and minds to it

– Inspired much of CA proposed reforms and processes (more later) – Jury still out on impacts to dental; “crowd out” remains big concern; dental is option rather than mandate for commercial marketplace. Money the issue. Policymakers would like to see dental included eventually
– Inspired much of CA proposed reforms and processes (more later)
– Jury still out on impacts to dental; “crowd out” remains big concern;
dental is option rather than mandate for commercial marketplace.
Money the issue. Policymakers would like to see dental included
eventually

Current State Issues - CA

• Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger negotiates with Democratic leaders over play or pay proposal
• Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger negotiates with
Democratic leaders over play or pay proposal

– Gov wants individual and business mandates, guarantee
– Gov wants individual and business mandates, guarantee

issue, with higher Medicaid reimbursement on the table along with hospital and physician tax and higher employer payroll tax
issue, with higher Medicaid reimbursement on the table along
with hospital and physician tax and higher employer payroll tax

– Dental included under proposed Medicaid and SCHIP
– Dental included under proposed Medicaid and SCHIP

expansion. Otherwise, not included but allowed as optional buy-up in state purchasing pool, and available to all mandated purchasers. Administration view consistent with Delta Dental/CADP priorities and principles. (See “principles”)
expansion. Otherwise, not included but allowed as optional
buy-up in state purchasing pool, and available to all mandated
purchasers. Administration view consistent with Delta
Dental/CADP priorities and principles. (See “principles”)

(PA) Gov. Ed Rendell proposes “Prescription for Pennsylvania”

– Sets up state health care agency, employer health levy, “individual
– Sets up state health care agency, employer health levy, “individual

wellness” tax and new health care board to finance and offer universal coverage, all with limited news/mention of dental
wellness” tax and new health care board to finance and offer
universal coverage, all with limited news/mention of dental

(MD) Legislature proposes tobacco tax-funded
universal health plan with individual and business
mandates

– Medicaid expansion and subsidies for small businesses through
state-purchasing pool; veto from more moderate Governor likely

– MD Dental Action Committee recommends: increased Medicaid

mandates for possible legislative intro in November

– (MN) …“Q-Care,” a pay-for-performance system promoted to save

containment proposal, with focus on hospital efficiency.

Opportunities for Oral Health: Developing a “Principled Stand”
Opportunities for Oral Health: O p p o r t u n i t i e s f o r
O r a l
H e a l t h :
Developing a “Principled Stand”

• Wanting a voice, dental industry offers principles to
• Wanting a voice, dental industry offers principles to

inform policymakers on opportunities
inform policymakers on opportunities

Principles are a common vehicle to help members measure proposals, advise the public and customers, and influence policymakers
Principles are a common vehicle to help members measure proposals,
advise the public and customers, and influence policymakers

Principles offer a way to respect local conditions, priorities and ways of doing things by region. What works in MA not necessarily best in CA
Principles offer a way to respect local conditions, priorities and ways of
doing things by region. What works in MA not necessarily best in CA

– Delta Dental, AHIP, NADP & CADP now unified on principles. ADA
– Delta Dental, AHIP, NADP & CADP now unified on principles. ADA

shares some goals, but politics makes collaboration difficult at best. Places where mutual interests occur will be chosen carefully.
shares some goals, but politics makes collaboration difficult at best.
Places where mutual interests occur will be chosen carefully.

Principles for Dental in Health Care Reform
Principles for Dental
in Health Care Reform

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

• Four fundamental observations inform industry’s
• Four fundamental observations inform industry’s

perspective on healthcare reform
perspective on healthcare reform

1. Dental is an inseparable part of health and overall wellness 2. Dental coverage creates affordable access for millions of Americans 3. Third party dental carriers add value, quality and control 4. Everyone deserves dental coverage; not everyone has it
1. Dental is an inseparable part of health and overall wellness
2. Dental coverage creates affordable access for millions of Americans
3. Third party dental carriers add value, quality and control
4. Everyone deserves dental coverage; not everyone has it

➢ Brief support for each of these included in the draft “Principles” document. ➢ Four observations followed by five policy implications.
➢ Brief support for each of these included in the draft “Principles” document. ➢ B r i e f

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

Policy Implication I
Policy Implication I

Proposals that inadvertently add cost to dental benefit administration and/or new barriers to the design of lower cost alternative plan designs will reduce access to affordable dental coverage, thereby diminishing oral health.
Proposals that inadvertently add cost to dental
benefit administration and/or new barriers to the
design of lower cost alternative plan designs will
reduce access to affordable dental coverage,
thereby diminishing oral health.

Preserving the deductibility of dental benefits for employers, employees and/or adding tax credits for individuals who purchase dental benefits on a voluntary basis is critical.
Preserving the deductibility of dental benefits for employers,
employees and/or adding tax credits for individuals who
purchase dental benefits on a voluntary basis is critical.

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

Policy Implication II
Policy Implication II

• Dental carriers should be encouraged — not hindered — in efforts to develop and enforce competitive fee arrangements, equitable reimbursement and dental policies, and innovative plan designs.
• Dental carriers should be encouraged — not
hindered — in efforts to develop and enforce
competitive fee arrangements, equitable
reimbursement and dental policies, and innovative
plan designs.

to ensure necessary and appropriate care in accordance with group contracts and high professional standards.
to ensure necessary and appropriate care in accordance with
group contracts and high professional standards.

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform

Policy Implication III
Policy Implication III

• Dental coverage should not be neglected in the
• Dental coverage should not be neglected in the

debate over how to fix healthcare.
debate over how to fix healthcare.

– Dental can be added into proposals or taken out, but in either
– Dental can be added into proposals or taken out, but in either

event, should be regarded carefully in view of the growing body of evidence that suggests control of caries and periodontal disease can improve health outcomes and reduce costs.
event, should be regarded carefully in view of the growing body
of evidence that suggests control of caries and periodontal
disease can improve health outcomes and reduce costs.

proposed reforms:
proposed reforms:

– Increase access to affordable care – Expand or build upon successful existing programs – Rely on qualified, experienced third party dental carriers (including
– Increase access to affordable care
– Expand or build upon successful existing programs
– Rely on qualified, experienced third party dental carriers (including

stand-alone dental carriers)
stand-alone dental carriers)

– Do not undermine healthy competition – Do not reduce employers’ and/or individuals’ capacity to retain
– Do not undermine healthy competition
– Do not reduce employers’ and/or individuals’ capacity to retain

existing dental benefit programs
existing dental benefit programs

– Do not jeopardize the tax-advantaged status of those who sponsor
– Do not jeopardize the tax-advantaged status of those who sponsor

and/or pay the cost of their own dental coverage.
and/or pay the cost of their own dental coverage.

Policy Implication V
Policy Implication V

• Health reform proposals should not:
• Health reform proposals should not: • H e a l t h
r e f o r m
p r o p o s a l s
s h o u l d
n o t :

– Extend only a limited scope dental program in a way that erodes
– Extend only a limited scope dental program in a way that erodes

existing, comprehensive dental benefit programs currently prevalent in the group benefits market place.
existing, comprehensive dental benefit programs currently
prevalent in the group benefits market place.

– Lead to a single-payer, government-sponsored agency that
– Lead to a single-payer, government-sponsored agency that

eliminates the critically important role of third party administration.
eliminates the critically important role of third party administration.

– Erect higher, more costly barriers to the development and offering
– Erect higher, more costly barriers to the development and offering

of cost-effective dental benefit programs
of cost-effective dental benefit programs

– Reduce the current portion of healthcare expenditures committed
– Reduce the current portion of healthcare expenditures committed

to dental treatment and coverage.
to dental treatment and coverage.

satisfied with what they have.

– “Divided We Fail” (AARP, Business Roundtable, SEIU) and “Health Care

coverage goal

benefits

Final Thoughts
Final Thoughts

• Bear in mind: It’s seldom about dental.
• Bear in mind: It’s seldom about dental.

– Most dental industry challenges in the government relations arena stem from laws and/or regulations that were not proposed with dental in mind.
– Most dental industry challenges in the government relations arena
stem from laws and/or regulations that were not proposed with
dental in mind.

– Our challenges continue to be shaped by larger forces: the
– Our challenges continue to be shaped by larger forces: the

increasing cost of healthcare, the backlash against managed care, the influx of immigrants, widening economic disparities within the population, the aging of the population and the divided electorate, to name only a few.
increasing cost of healthcare, the backlash against managed care,
the influx of immigrants, widening economic disparities within the
population, the aging of the population and the divided electorate,
to name only a few.
